Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_0.name: 17e3
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_0.text: How to search with Android Jetpack?

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_2.text: Some time ago we learned how to do a search on Android with SearchView. Not only pure UI component which consumes your typos, but more: makes your Activity SEARCHABLE â€” e.g. providing search suggestions, voice search, etc:

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_4.name: 62a1
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_4.text: I am not sure you are familiar with searchables, but thereâ€™s a lot of ceremonies to do so â€” we need to touch several XMLs:

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_5.name: efd7
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_5.text: AndroidManifest(add android.intent.action.SEARCH intent-filter to your target Activity).

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_7.text: edit some res/layout â€” put some additional properties to SearchView ðŸ˜€

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_8.name: 9e36
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_8.text: Apart from that, you still need to dodge some Android gotchas â€” like singleTop flag for your activity, overriding onNewIntent() and so on... I know implementing search is a pain, but itâ€™s doable ðŸ˜…

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_9.name: fc89
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_9.text: Letâ€™s think about voice search â€” some people prefer to talk, rather than write. Whatâ€™s more, when the user relies on 3rd party keyboard(and it breaks for some reason), itâ€™s quite convenient having a fallback for searching via voice. We, Android guys are happy to configure voice search to make it possible:

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_10.name: 582b
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_10.text: Just a little mike on the right. Right?

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_14.name: a418
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_14.text: Android ecosystem evolves, so does the guidelines and design decisions. Searchable fits well for an individual screen â€” a single activity that is responsible for doing one operation ðŸ”Ž. This is a bit obsolete now, thus we can already have the single activity with dozens of fragments inside. What will happen if we decide to put into our app more than one search ðŸ”? In other words â€” how to deal with many voice search features in single activity architecture? ðŸ” ðŸ”Ž

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_16.name: 775c
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_16.text: When we click on the microphone icon in SearchView, search by voice is triggered and the result is delivered back via activityâ€™s onNewIntent(Intent). How can we distinguish which of the SearchView has triggered this search, and update UI accordingly? If we deal with a single fragment on the screen â€” this is fine, but what about foldable /multi-window apps /many fragments on the same screen?

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_18.name: da73
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_18.text: 1. Naive approach â€” store information where searched recently

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_19.name: 92d5
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_19.text: One of the solution is to keep which of the search queried recently. We need to keep that tiny portion of data somewhere. Beware SharedPreferences, or databases â€” we donâ€™t want to use cannon to kill a mosquito. It probably needs to be cleared if your user logs outâ€¦ We need to make it volatile as much as possible.

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_21.name: 7d3a
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_21.text: Keeping information in onSavedInstanceState bundle looks promising but wait â€” it is really needed?

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_22.name: 8c12
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_22.text: 3. Diving into SearchView API ðŸŽ‰ ðŸŽ‰ ðŸŽ‰

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_23.name: 74f5
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_23.text: It turns out that we can dodge our problem with little hack regarding SearchView:

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_27.name: 3e28
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_27.text: How does it work? It is possible to configure SearchView with search data â€” we can pass bundle for (external) voice search dialog. When our activity is calling onNewIntent thereafter with the result, the intent already contains the bundle we passed before. A lot betterðŸ‘Œ

Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_29.name: 48a7
Paragraph:ec4d6358991c_29.text:
Riddle presented here is available on Github ðŸ™ ðŸ˜º HERE
I used LordsOfTheRings API for sample content ðŸ˜
(searching hobbits ðŸ’ or elves ðŸ¹)
